data.description:
Problem statement
-----------------
The scheduler must automatically triage in-progress Worklog items: every 2 minutes fetch `wl in-progress --json`, pick the item with the oldest `updatedAt` (least recently updated), run `opencode run audit <work-item-id>` against it, deliver a short summary to the configured Discord webhook, and post the full audit (truncated if necessary) as a comment on the work item.

Users
-----
- Operators and PMs who rely on timely visibility into stalled or neglected in-progress work items.
- The APMA / AMPA automation that needs regular audits surfaced to Slack/Discord and Worklog for human review.

Example user stories
- As an operator, I want the scheduler to alert the team when an in-progress item has not been updated for a long time, so I can reassign or unblock it.
- As an APMA integrator, I want automated audits posted to work items so humans have evidence of health checks and suggested next steps.

Success criteria
----------------
- Scheduler runs every 2 minutes and executes the triage flow end-to-end (fetch -> select -> audit -> deliver) with measurable logs.
- For each run: a short (1–3 line) summary is posted to Discord (via `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK`) and a concise summary comment is posted on the audited WL work item.
- Full audit output is attached to the work item as a comment (up to 64k chars); if longer, the comment references an attached artifact containing the full output.
- The system handles transient failures by relying on the global retry/backoff policy (no local retry logic implemented in this feature); any final failure is recorded as an error comment on the work item.

Constraints
-----------
- Use the global `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` environment variable for Discord delivery; do not embed webhook secrets in code or comments.
- Poll interval is configurable but defaults to every 2 minutes for this feature.
- No local retry logic will be implemented here; the feature defers to the global retry/backoff work (see SA-0ML7OB0NX0Z9T0YV). Implementation must be ready to integrate with a global retry later.
- Audit output may be large; comments must be truncated to 64k characters and include or link to an attached full-output artifact when necessary.
 - No single work item should be audited more frequently than once every 6 hours. Implementations must record a per-work-item `last_audit_at` timestamp and skip items audited within the cooldown window.

Existing state
--------------
- Scheduler and AMPA daemon exist and already support scheduled commands, Discord webhook posting, and `wl in-progress` as a scheduled command (see `ampa/scheduler.py` and `ampa/scheduler_store.json`).
- Related scheduler improvements and defaults have been implemented (moving heartbeat into scheduler config, switching to `wl in-progress`, plain-text webhook payloads).

Desired change / Implementation notes
-----------------------------------
- Add a new scheduler command spec (default in `ampa/scheduler_store.json`) named `wl-triage-audit` with frequency 2 minutes and metadata indicating it performs: `wl in-progress --json` -> select least-recently-updated -> `opencode run audit <id>`.
- Implement executor logic to:
  1) run `wl in-progress --json` and parse result;
  2) select the work item with the smallest `updatedAt` timestamp among those that have not been audited within the configured cooldown window (default 6 hours). If all in-progress items have been audited within the cooldown, the scheduler should skip the run.
  3) run `opencode run audit <work-item-id>` and capture stdout/stderr and exit status;
  4) post a short 1–3 line summary to the Discord webhook configured in `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` (include work-item id, title, and short status/exit code);
  5) post the full audit output as a comment on the work item, truncating the comment body at 64k characters and attaching the full output as an artifact if larger.
- Error handling: if an operation (wl in-progress, audit, discord post, wl comment) fails transiently, rely on global retry; on final failure post a WL comment with an error summary and log the failure.
- Config options to expose: `poll_interval_minutes` (default 2), `webhook_env_var` (default AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK), `workitem_comment_truncate_chars` (default 65536), and `verbosity` (summary vs verbose).
  - `audit_cooldown_hours` (default 6) — minimum time between audits of the same work item; implementers should persist `last_audit_at` on the item or in the scheduler store.

Related work
------------
- AMPA Daemon: Discord heartbeat & notifier — SA-0ML7NOSHP0MJC6HS (parent project; scheduler lives under this parent).
- Move heartbeat to scheduler config and add wl recent command — SA-0ML8QRQXC12R12DF (moved heartbeat into scheduler; related config work).
- Update scheduled commands to wl in-progress and wl stats — SA-0ML8VDYT303CDIWD (updated defaults to use `wl in-progress`).
- Scheduler daemon updates and docs — SA-0ML95LRFD08CS2CZ (scheduler cwd / docs changes already applied).
- Fix scheduler wl stats command — SA-0ML8XKRV80GORAL7 (related scheduler command fixes)
- Core Heartbeat Sender — SA-0ML7OB0H20XBQO6G (discord webhook formatting and retry policies; shared code paths).
- Implementation references: `ampa/scheduler.py`, `ampa/scheduler_schema.md`, `ampa/scheduler_store.json`, `AGENTS.md`, `skill/status/SKILL.md`.

Suggested next steps
--------------------
1) Proceed to implement a scheduler command and executor stub (create feature branch, add tests to cover happy path and error comment path). This step involves adding the scheduler store entry, implementing selection + audit invocation, and wiring Discord/comment posting. (Recommended next step)
2) Add integration tests that run the triage flow against a mocked `wl` and `opencode run` to verify idempotence, comment truncation and artifact attachment.
3) After implementation, update the Worklog work item description with this intake brief and mark stage `intake_complete`.

Notes / Open questions
----------------------
- We will use `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` as the webhook; if you want per-scheduler-entry webhooks, we can add `spec.metadata.webhook` as a fallback later.
- The feature defers to the global retry/backoff policy (SA-0ML7OB0NX0Z9T0YV). If you prefer local retries now, specify and we will add them.

data.description:
Problem statement
There is probable duplicated or overlapping logic between `ampa/daemon.py` and `ampa/scheduler.py` that increases maintenance burden and risks divergent behaviour. This intake will produce a short analysis recommending consolidation options and next steps.

Users
- Maintainers who must fix or extend webhook, scheduling, or command-execution behaviour.
- Developers writing tests and features that touch scheduler/daemon logic.

User stories
- As a maintainer, I want a small analysis that lists where code overlaps so I can plan a safe consolidation.
- As a developer, I want a recommendation that preserves public scheduler APIs and explains test gaps so refactors do not break callers.

Success criteria
- Deliver a concise analysis (high-level overlap summary) showing the areas of likely duplication and a recommendation for canonical source (prefer `ampa/scheduler.py`).
- Produce a clear next-step: post a Worklog comment summarizing findings and create child tasks for extraction, tests, and follow-ups (if approved).
- Do not propose changes to public scheduler interfaces; list test gaps to be addressed before refactor.

Constraints
- Preserve public scheduler CLI and API behaviour: avoid interface changes in the recommended approach.
- Analysis-only outcome: no code changes will be made as part of this intake.
- Respect repository ignore rules and do not surface contents of ignored files.

Existing state
- Files of interest: `ampa/daemon.py` and `ampa/scheduler.py` both implement webhook sending, payload building, and environment-based configuration. Tests reference `ampa.daemon` widely (see tests under `tests/`).
- The work item SA-0MLAB9VKQ01ALR3M has been marked `in_progress`/`idea` and assigned to Map.

Desired change
- Produce an analysis document that: identifies overlapping responsibilities at a high level (functions/classes/modules involved), recommends making `ampa.daemon` the primary service entrypoint (so runtime is started via the daemon) while keeping `ampa.scheduler` as the canonical scheduler implementation and preserving its public CLI. List concrete, low-risk next actions (create child work items, list tests to add, and propose extraction points) while preserving public scheduler interfaces.

Related work
- Files (potentially related docs):
  - `ampa/daemon.py` 1: primary daemon logic used by unit tests and scheduler calls
  - `ampa/scheduler.py` 1: scheduler driver that currently imports/uses `ampa.daemon` and duplicates webhook/command payload logic
  - `ampa/README.md` 1: run instructions and environment variable guidance
  - `ampa/scheduler_schema.md` 1: scheduler command schema and store layout
  - `tests/` (examples referencing daemon): `tests/test_retries.py`, `tests/test_state_behavior.py`, `tests/test_triage_audit.py`

- Potentially related work items (single-line summaries):
  - AMPA Daemon: Discord heartbeat & notifier 1 `SA-0ML7NOSHP0MJC6HS` 1: parent project for daemon/scheduler features
  - Core Heartbeat Sender 1 `SA-0ML7OB0H20XBQO6G` 1: heartbeat sender, webhook formatting and retry logic
  - Retry Policy & Backoff 1 `SA-0ML7OB0NX0Z9T0YV` 1: retry/backoff behaviour referenced by daemon/scheduler
  - Scheduler: issue triage (automatic wl in-progress audits) 1 `SA-0ML96LPVC19CD40C` 1: scheduler command that runs audits and posts to WL/Discord

Brief summaries of related artifacts
- `ampa/daemon.py`: implements webhook payload building and send logic; referenced directly by tests and scheduler; contains retry/dead-letter handling used in unit tests.
- `ampa/scheduler.py`: persistent scheduler store, command selection and executor, and code paths that call into or reimplement webhook/payload sending; includes examples of scheduler commands that call `daemon` functions.
- `ampa/scheduler_schema.md`: documents scheduler store fields and expected command metadata; helpful to preserve scheduler public contract.
- Tests under `tests/`: exercise send_webhook and build payload behaviours via `ampa.daemon` and also run scheduler simulations; these indicate which behaviours must be preserved by any consolidation.
- WL items: several related work items exist (IDs above) describing heartbeat, retry policy, triage, and scheduler improvements; these show the broader design intent and dependencies.

Suggested next steps (first is progression required by intake process)
1) Progress: Post this analysis summary as a Worklog comment on `SA-0MLAB9VKQ01ALR3M` and create child tasks (assign to Map) for: (a) implement the daemon-as-entrypoint change (small PR adding CLI flags and starting the scheduler from the daemon), (b) extract shared helpers into `ampa/webhook.py` (small follow-up), and (c) document test gaps. This step involves creating the WL comment and child work items and scheduling the 3-day analysis window.
2) If approved: run a targeted review that lists overlapping functions/classes (high-level only) and produces a gated checklist of tests to add before any refactor.
3) After the analysis: implement a small extraction PR that moves shared webhook/payload functions into `ampa/webhook.py`, keeps `ampa/daemon.py` as the runtime entrypoint and shim for compatibility, and updates scheduler imports to use the shared helpers while preserving its CLI.

Open questions for the author/user
- Do you want the analysis to include annotated code snippets (line-level) or only high-level descriptions? (Current preference: high-level only)
- Confirm we must not alter scheduler public CLI/APIs during refactor (affirmed).
- Do you want a separate child task created specifically to run automated semantic diffs (e.g., using a tool) or should the manual analysis suffice?

Timeline & priority
- Priority: `critical` (unchanged). Target delivery for the analysis summary: within 3 business days from approval.

Summary:
Add a set of scripted, well-tested routines that automate the actions currently performed by the "cleanup" skill so most cleanup tasks can be executed non-interactively and reproducibly.

User stories:
- As a repository maintainer, I want a set of scripts that perform common cleanup actions (prune merged branches, remove local merged branches, tidy remote branches, close or update resolved work items, and generate a cleanup report) so I can reduce manual effort and human error.
- As an automation engineer, I want these routines to support a dry-run mode and be idempotent so they are safe to run in CI or locally.

Expected behaviour:
- Scripts live under `scripts/cleanup/` (or `tools/cleanup/`) and are cross-platform where possible (POSIX sh / Python).  
- Each routine supports `--dry-run`, `--yes` (non-interactive), and configurable logging/verbosity.  
- Routines perform safe checks before destructive actions and produce a machine-readable report (JSON) summarising changes.  
- Automated tests (unit + integration dry-run) cover the core behaviours.

Acceptance criteria (measurable):
1. A repo path `scripts/cleanup/` (or `tools/cleanup/`) exists with at least 3 scripts implementing:  
   a) pruning local branches merged into main,  
   b) listing and optionally deleting stale remote branches older than X days,  
   c) reconciling worklog items (closing/annotating items matched by rules) and producing a JSON report.
2. Each script supports `--dry-run` and `--yes` flags and exits without making changes on dry-run.
3. Unit tests and a CI job (or GH Actions workflow stub) run the scripts in dry-run mode and pass.
4. Scripts include clear README documentation with examples and required configuration.
5. The implementation references the existing cleanup skill: `/home/rogardle/.config/opencode/skill/cleanup/SKILL.md` and documents any behaviour differences.

Suggested implementation approach:
- Prototype routines in Python (recommended) for portability, packaged under `scripts/cleanup/` with an entrypoint `scripts/cleanup/run_cleanup.py`.
- Provide a small CLI helper library `scripts/cleanup/lib.py` that implements dry-run and logging and can be unit-tested.
- Add tests under `tests/cleanup/` that assert dry-run behaviour and report format.
- Add a CI job `ci/cleanup.yml` (or update existing CI) that runs tests and dry-run checks.

Notes / Risks:
- Destructive operations require careful defaults and confirmation; implement safe dry-run as default in CI.
- May require additional permissions for remote operations (GH tokens) — ensure scripts have clear configuration for credentials and explicit opt-in for remote deletions.

Related:
- cleanup skill: `/home/rogardle/.config/opencode/skill/cleanup/SKILL.md`

data.description:
Problem statement
---------------
A scheduled scheduler task that prevents agent thrash by checking for any in-progress work items already assigned to agents; if none exist it discovers the next ready work item (`wl next`) and notifies a configured webhook recommending which agent should be assigned and what action to take: "Perform intake interview on <work-item-id>", "Create plan for <work-item-id>", or "Implement <work-item-id>".

Users
-----
- Operators / automation owners: want predictable, low-noise delegation so agents receive clear instructions and work is not double-assigned.
- APMA / agent orchestrator: uses the scheduler to seed intake/plan/implement flows when capacity is available.
- Agents (Map, Patch, etc.): receive clear, actionable instructions via webhook and act upon them.

Success criteria
----------------
- The scheduler runs on a 2-minute cadence and produces at most one notification per eligible work item (idempotent behavior).
- If any in-progress work item is assigned to an eligible agent, the scheduler performs no-op and does not notify.
- When no blocking in-progress assignment exists the scheduler finds the `wl next --json` item and sends a plain-text Discord webhook message (env: `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK`) containing: agent, work-item id, short title, and one instruction chosen from the three allowed commands.
- Instruction selection follows stage+complexity heuristic: idea+complex → "Perform intake interview"; idea+simple → "Implement"; intake_complete → "Create plan"; plan_complete → "Implement". Complexity is inferred using a text heuristic weighted by number of affected files and number of related work items (files have higher weight).
- Notification is webhook-only (no WL mutation). The scheduler avoids duplicate notifications by checking for an existing suggestion comment on the work item and skipping if present.

Constraints
-----------
- Delivery uses the existing Discord webhook env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` (no secrets in code).
- Poll cadence default: every 2 minutes (configurable).
- Complexity detection must be conservative and explainable; use: priority override (high/critical → complex) and otherwise a text heuristic that includes affected-files count + related-items count.
- Eligible agents: Map and Patch (routing mapping: Intake → Map; Plan → Map; Implement → Patch). When checking for blocking in-progress items, only assignments to the eligible agent set count.
- Idempotence: before sending a notification check work item comments for a prior suggestion (exact-match detection) and skip if found.

Existing state
--------------
- Worklog item created for this intake: `SA-0MLAJV8J30E7G3RM` (Scheduler: select-and-assign-next-wl-item (intake delegator)).
- Related scheduler work exists in repo: `SA-0ML96LPVC19CD40C` (Scheduler: issue triage) and AMPA daemon items (heartbeat/notifier) which show existing patterns for webhook delivery and scheduling cadence.
- A design artifact/skill exists for selecting next intake-ready items: `SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE` (select-next-intake-ready-item) which may overlap or be a consumer of this scheduler.

Desired change
--------------
- Implement a lightweight scheduler process that:
  1) Runs every 2 minutes; 2) calls `wl in-progress --json` and inspects assignments filtered to the eligible agent set; if any found, exit no-op.
  2) If none found, call `wl next --json` to locate the next ready work item; fetch work item metadata (`wl show <id> --json`) including stage, priority, tags, related children, and any affected-files metadata if present.
  3) Compute complexity using: priority override + text heuristic that counts affected files and related items (files weighted higher). If insufficient metadata is present, fallback to conservative path: request intake (i.e., treat as complex).
  4) Choose target agent using mapping: Intake→Map, Plan→Map, Implement→Patch.
  5) Compose and POST a plain-text message to `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` with the recommended instruction and agent.
  6) Before posting, verify no existing suggestion comment exists on the work item (use comment detect helper if available) to ensure idempotence.

Related work
------------
- Scheduler: issue triage — `SA-0ML96LPVC19CD40C`: existing scheduler that audits in-progress items and posts to Discord; use as implementation reference for polling, webhook posting, and comment posting patterns.
- AMPA Daemon: Discord heartbeat & notifier — `SA-0ML7NOSHP0MJC6HS`: reference for webhook usage and containerization/run guidance.
- select-next-intake-ready-item — `SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE`: related skill that discovers next intake-ready items; consider integration or reuse.
- owner_inference / owner-detection skills — `SA-0MKZVABOH1I8OLXA`: possible enhancement for more advanced agent selection later.

Suggested next steps (first is progression required by intake process)
---------------------------------------------------------------
1) Approve this draft so the five intake review passes can run; after reviews we will update `SA-0MLAJV8J30E7G3RM` with the final brief and mark stage `intake_complete`.
2) Implement a minimal PoC scheduler (script or small service) that runs the selection logic without mutating WL, posts to `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK`, and respects idempotence checks; add unit tests.
3) Iterate: add better complexity signals (affected_files field, related-items count) and integrate with `owner_inference` if needed.

data.description:
Implement a Worklog (wl) plugin named 'ampa' that provides a lightweight project-scoped daemon supervisor with three top-level commands:

- wl ampa start — start the project daemon (detached by default)
- wl ampa stop  — stop the running daemon for the project
- wl ampa status— report the daemon status (running PID, uptime, log location)

Notes / assumptions:
- The user wrote 'wl amps stop' but we assume that was a typo and the intended command is 'wl ampa stop'. If that was intentional, please update the work item after creation.

Behavior / detection:
- When invoked from any directory inside a project with a worklog, the plugin should locate the project root by walking parents until a worklog marker is found (e.g. worklog.json, .worklog directory) or until .git is found as a fallback.
- The plugin changes into the project root and runs the configured daemon command for that project.

Daemon command resolution (priority):
1. CLI --cmd ... flag (optional)
2. Environment variable WL_AMPA_CMD
3. Project config (in order): worklog.json (new ampa key), package.json scripts.ampa, Procfile entry ampa, executable ./scripts/ampa or ./scripts/daemon if present
4. If none found, fail with clear error and suggestions.

Runtime behavior:
- By default start detaches the process, writes pid and metadata to .worklog/ampa/ampa.pid and logs to .worklog/ampa/ampa.log.
- --foreground runs in foreground (no detach) and streams logs to stdout.
- stop reads pid file, attempts graceful TERM then SIGKILL after a timeout, and removes pid file on success.
- status reports running/stopped, PID, uptime, and log path. If PID exists but process dead, clear stale pid file and report stopped.
- Support --name <name> to allow multiple named daemons within a project (pid/log located under .worklog/ampa/<name>.(pid|log)). Default name: default.

Resilience & production guidance:
- Provide an optional --restart incremental/backoff basic restart loop for local development (not a full supervisor). Recommend systemd/launchd/pm2 for production.

Acceptance criteria (testable):
- wl ampa start starts the resolved command detached and writes a PID and log file under .worklog/ampa/.
- wl ampa status accurately reports running state and metadata.
- wl ampa stop stops a running daemon and cleans up pid metadata.
- Plugin honors --foreground, --cmd, --name, and WL_AMPA_CMD.
- Unit tests cover root detection, command resolution, pid/log management, and stop behavior (mocking process spawn where appropriate).
- Integration test (script-based) that runs a short-lived test daemon (e.g. sleep loop that writes a heartbeat) and validates start/status/stop lifecycle.
- Documentation added to repository tooling docs and wl plugin registration (README + example worklog.json snippet).

Implementation notes / suggested approach:
- Implement as a wl plugin (subcommand) in Go to match wl tooling (single binary, cross-platform). Keep code small and dependency-light.
- Use a Go library to locate repository root (walk parents) and to manage subprocesses (os/exec). Write pid/log files under .worklog/ampa/.
- Provide clear logging and exit codes for automation.

Deliverables:
- New worktree/branch: wl-ampa-plugin (or wl-created branch naming convention)
- Implementation code + unit tests
- Basic e2e script for lifecycle test
- Docs: README section and worklog.json example
data.title: Implement wl ampa plugin (start/stop/status)

Files changed: plugins/install-worklog-plugin.sh. This change improves safety and diagnostics for ampa plugin installs.

data.description:
The ampa plugin installer script (plugins/install-worklog-plugin.sh) has grown to 480 lines with complex conditional logic for webhook configuration, virtual environment setup, daemon restart, and environment file preservation.

## Current Issues

1. **Complexity**: The script has grown to handle too many concerns at once:
   - Locking and concurrency control
   - Argument parsing
   - Upgrade decision flow
   - Webhook prompting and configuration
   - Python dependency installation and venv management
   - Environment file handling and preservation
   - Daemon restart logic

2. **Maintainability**: Logic is difficult to follow with deeply nested conditionals and state management across multiple decision points

3. **Testability**: Hard to unit test individual concerns; e2e testing is the main avenue

4. **Error handling**: Some paths lack clear error reporting (e.g., venv creation failures)

5. **Portability**: Some bash patterns may not work across all POSIX-compliant shells

## Proposed Refactoring Goals

- Decompose the installer into smaller, focused functions with clear responsibilities
- Improve error handling and reporting with better messaging
- Make webhook and environment file handling more explicit and easier to understand
- Extract testable units where possible
- Preserve all existing functionality and behavior
- Maintain backward compatibility with current CLI interface
- Improve shell compatibility (POSIX-compliant)
- Add better logging/tracing for debugging installation issues

## Expected Outcomes

- Improved code quality and maintainability
- Clearer separation of concerns
- Better error messages for users
- Easier to add new features or modify behavior in the future
data.title: Refactor worklog ampa plugin installer

data.description: When the AMPA worklog plugin is installed, if no scheduler_store.json exists, it should be initialized by copying scheduler_store_example.json to scheduler_store.json. Additionally, when the plugin is upgraded/reinstalled, the existing scheduler_store.json file must be preserved (similar to how .env files are typically preserved during upgrades). Currently, no scheduled commands are run because the store file is missing, which causes the scheduler to have no commands to execute.
data.title: Fix scheduler_store.json initialization in AMPA plugin

data.description:
The install-worklog-plugin.sh script removes the entire ampa_py/ampa directory and copies it fresh, which loses the scheduler_store.json file if one exists. This needs to be fixed to:

1. Back up scheduler_store.json before removing the old ampa directory (similar to how .env is backed up)
2. Restore scheduler_store.json after copying the new ampa package

The script already has the machinery for this (backup_env_file, restore_env_file functions) - we just need to apply it to scheduler_store.json as well.
data.title: Preserve scheduler_store.json during AMPA plugin installation

data.description: When installing the AMPA worklog plugin for the first time, the installer should automatically start the daemon to ensure the plugin is immediately functional. Previously, the daemon was only restarted if a daemon was already running and the user confirmed the restart.

data.description:
Summary:
Adjust the existing 'implement' skill so that it first checks the target work item's description for related work items. If related items are present it should proceed as today. If not, the implement skill must call a new skill (name suggestion: 'intake_or_find_related') that will decide whether an intake is required or whether there is enough information to search for related items and perform that search.

User story:
As an agent using the 'implement' skill I want the skill to automatically ensure a work item has related items (or run a lightweight intake) before implementation starts, so the implement flow has the necessary context and does not proceed with insufficient information.

Expected behaviour:
- When 'implement' is invoked on a work item, it checks the work item's description for mentions of related items (e.g. tags or keywords such as 'related-to:', 'discovered-from:', or explicit work item ids).
- If related items exist, implement continues without calling the new skill.
- If no related items are found, implement calls the new 'intake_or_find_related' skill.
  - That skill decides if an intake is required (per intake rules); if yes, it performs the intake (creating/updating the work item to include intake details) and returns updated work item metadata.
  - If intake is not required but not enough context exists, it proceeds to search for related items (using existing worklog queries or heuristics) and appends found related item references to the work item description.
- After the new skill completes, implement re-checks the description for related items and proceeds if present. If still missing required context, implement should fail with a clear, testable error.

Suggested implementation approach:
1) Modify the 'implement' skill entry point to parse the work item description for related markers. Define clear patterns to match (e.g. /related-to:\s*([A-Za-z0-9\-_, ]+)/i and tags like discovered-from:<id>).
2) If none found, call a new skill module 'intake_or_find_related' that exposes a simple interface: input: work-item-id (and optionally current description); output: {intakePerformed: boolean, relatedFound: boolean, updatedDescription: string, addedRelatedIds: [ids]}.
3) Implement acceptance logic: if intakePerformed then re-evaluate; if relatedFound append to description and continue; else return a controlled error.
4) Add unit tests for both skills and an integration test that simulates the implement flow when a work item has/doesn't have related items.

Acceptance criteria:
- A new work item is created for this change and references to modified files are listed in task comments when work is done.
- The 'implement' skill checks for related items in the description and calls the new 'intake_or_find_related' skill only when none are present.
- The new 'intake_or_find_related' skill exists and either performs an intake (creating/updating intake details) or searches for related items and updates the work item description.
- Tests: unit tests covering parsing logic, new skill decision branches; an integration/unit test demonstrating the full flow where implement calls the new skill and proceeds when related items are added.
- No existing behaviour is broken for cases where related items already exist.

Files/areas likely affected:
- skill/implement (implementation code)
- new skill file: skill/intake_or_find_related (or similar path)
- tests/ (add tests for parsing/decision/integration)
- worklog usage in skills that query/search work items

Notes & risks:
- Careful with parsing false positives — keep matching conservative.
- Ensure the new skill respects rate limits / side effects when creating items.
- Keep changes backwards compatible.

Next steps:
- Assign to an implementer to create branch, implement changes and add tests.

Acceptance tests (minimal):
1) Work item A has a description containing 'related-to: WL-123' -> run implement -> implement proceeds and does not call the new skill.
2) Work item B has no related items -> run implement -> implement calls new skill which performs a search and appends 'related-to: WL-321' -> implement proceeds.
3) Work item C has no related items and intake is required -> new skill performs intake (updates description with intake summary) and returns; implement proceeds only when intake rules satisfied.
data.title: implement: check for related items before running - create intake/search skill

    "description": "Summary:
Design, define, and build an Automated PM Agent (APMA) that acts as a discovery, definition, and delegation engine to coordinate delivery across human and automated sub-agents. The APMA's responsibility is to ensure clarity of plan, break down work into actionable tasks, assign or delegate those tasks, and monitor progress — it does not implement code changes or directly modify repositories.

Goal / Scope:
The APMA intake flow accepts briefs and performs discovery to surface candidate work, creates clear work definitions (analysis, design, implementation spec, test plan, docs), and delegates those tasks to appropriate agents or teams. It sequences and coordinates work, triggers or requests non-destructive checks (builds/tests in read-only mode), and reports status, risks, and blockers. All code or repository modifications are executed by delegated agents (people or automation) under explicit approval policies.

User stories:
- As a product lead, I want the APMA to turn a high-level brief into a clear plan with defined tasks and assignees so work can start without ambiguous follow-ups.
- As an engineer or sub-agent, I want the APMA to produce unambiguous child work-items (analysis, design spec, implementation spec, tests, docs) with acceptance criteria so I can execute my assigned work with minimal additional discovery.
- As a stakeholder, I want the APMA to delegate work to named agents, maintain an audit trail of delegation actions, and produce regular progress reports so I can monitor delivery.
- As a safety officer, I want the APMA to default to read-only discovery and never perform destructive repo operations without explicit separate approval.

Expected behaviour / outcomes:
- The APMA discovers and ranks candidate items from `idea` stage, runs readiness checks, and returns a clear recommended plan with proposed child tasks and suggested assignees/agent-groups.
- The APMA can create draft child work-items or add delegation comments in `wl` to record what should be done and who should do it; it may assign tasks to agent identities but will not perform repository pushes, merges, or direct code edits.
- The APMA coordinates non-destructive operations (CI runs in dry-run mode, linting, static analysis) and attaches results to work-items; any mutating repository actions are delegated and require separate approvals.
- The APMA generates progress summaries (open/blocked items, percent complete, top risks) and maintains an auditable comment trail for decisions and delegations.
- The APMA can also generate new ideas for exploration (research spikes, prototypes, alternative approaches) and surface them as candidate `idea`-stage work-items for further discovery.
- The APMA can respond clearly about the status of any particular work-item or group of work-items, providing current stage, recent activity, assigned agents, blockers, and next recommended actions.

Acceptance criteria:
1) Given a project brief, the APMA creates an epic with child work-items that define discovery tasks, analysis, design, implementation spec, testing, and documentation steps with measurable acceptance criteria in `wl`.
2) The APMA can produce a delegation plan for a selected work-item: a list of proposed child tasks, suggested assignee agent-groups, and the rationale for each delegation (verify: `wl show` and comments reflect proposed tasks and rationale).
3) The APMA provides read-only discovery by default; `propose` or `delegate` actions create draft child work-items or comments but do not modify code repositories. Any `apply` mode that triggers repository changes must be explicitly approved and executed by delegated agents.
4) The APMA produces human-readable progress reports and an audit trail of delegation actions attached to the relevant work-items.

Suggested implementation approach:
- Phase 1 (define): Create PRD, agent responsibilities, safety/permission model, and minimal architecture (core controller + plug-in subagents for wl, delegation, reporting).
- Phase 2 (MVP): Implement intake parser, discovery scorer, task composer, delegation planner (creates draft child work-items and comments), and reporting module. Keep all repo-affecting steps as outputs for delegated agents.
- Phase 3 (operate): Integrate with sub-agents (analysis-agent, design-agent, dev-agent, test-agent), refine delegation mappings, and add audit and reporting enhancements.

Deliverables:
- PRD and design doc stored in the repo describing discovery/definition/delegation model and safety policy.
- APMA components (service/CLI) that implement the MVP acceptance criteria above, but do not perform direct repository mutations.
- Tests validating `wl` creations, proposed delegations, and reporting behavior.

Notes / constraints:
- APMA is non-destructive by default: repository changes are outside its remit and must be performed by delegates under separate approvals.
- Follow repo conventions for task naming, branch suggestions, and commit message drafts; these should be provided as outputs for delegates, not applied by APMA.
- Maintain clear audit logs in work-items when delegations or proposals are created.

Acceptance test steps:
- Run APMA with a sample brief and verify an epic is created with well-defined child tasks: `wl show <epic-id>`.
- Verify the APMA produced a delegation plan and comments suggesting assignees/agent-groups for child tasks.
- Confirm APMA's operations did not perform any repository pushes or merges; repository-affecting steps are present as delegated outputs only.
- Generate the APMA progress report and confirm it lists open/blocked items, percent complete, and top risks.

Create a reusable "select-next-intake-ready-item" skill that discovers and defines the next worklog item in the `idea` stage which should be advanced to `intake_complete`, and then delegates the resulting tasks to appropriate sub-agents for execution. This skill is part of the APMA's discovery and planning toolset: it focuses on surfacing ready work, producing clear task definitions, and assigning/delegating those tasks — the APMA coordinates delivery but does not perform the implementation work itself.

Goal:
Provide a deterministic, configurable function/skill that can search worklog (wl) for candidate items, run readiness checks, produce a structured task definition (including acceptance criteria and suggested subtasks), and recommend or delegate the item to one or more sub-agents (e.g., analysis-agent, design-agent, dev-agent, test-agent). The skill must support a read-only discovery mode and a delegation mode that creates the appropriate child work-items or adds delegation comments, but it must not modify code repositories directly.

User stories:
- As the APMA, I want the skill to answer "what should be moved from idea -> intake_complete next?" and return a single work-item id plus a clear plan of what needs to be done and who should do it.
- As an engineer or agent, I want the APMA to produce unambiguous child tasks (analysis, design spec, implementation spec, tests, docs) with acceptance criteria so I can act without extra discovery work.
- As a stakeholder, I want the APMA to delegate tasks to the right sub-agents and provide a communication trail (work-item comments and assignments) so responsibility and progress are clear.
- As a safety officer, I want the APMA to run in read-only mode by default and never perform destructive repository actions — delegation triggers agents who are responsible for code changes under human or delegated policy approvals.

Acceptance criteria:
1) The skill returns a JSON structure with: `id`, `score`, `rationale`, `checks` (list of passed/failed readiness checks), `proposed_tasks` (array of child task definitions), and `action` (suggested: `recommend` | `delegate`).
2) The skill respects filters: only search `idea` stage, allow override tag filters, and allow minimum priority threshold.
3) The skill supports `dry_run` (discovery-only), `propose` (creates draft child work-items in wl but does not assign or change stage), and `delegate` mode (creates/assigns child tasks to named agents or agent-groups; still read-only regarding repositories). Any state changes require explicit approval or delegate policy.
4) The skill includes unit tests mocking `wl` outputs and verifying selection, task-definition, and delegation logic.

Implementation notes:
- Implement as a Python module under `tools/skills/select_next_intake.py` with a thin CLI and a function interface for other agents to call.
- Data access uses `wl` for authoritative state (e.g. `wl list --stage idea --json`) but provide an injectable data-source abstraction for tests and simulations.
- Output includes: readiness checks, scoring breakdown, proposed child tasks (title, description, acceptance criteria, suggested assignee/agent, priority), and a human-readable plan summary.
- Scoring: start simple (priority weight, has_acceptance_criteria, has_assignee, no_open_blockers); expose weights in config.
- Logging: structured logs and a short human-readable rationale; all delegation actions must record comments on work-items describing what was delegated and to whom.

SKILL.md (first draft):

---
# select-next-intake-ready-item Skill

Purpose
- Discover the next worklog item in `idea` stage that is ready to move into intake and produce a clear, actionable plan that can be delegated to sub-agents. The skill focuses on discovery, definition, and delegation — the APMA coordinates work and ensures clarity, but does not directly modify code or repos.

How it works
- Searches worklog for items in `idea` stage.
- Runs readiness checks and computes a score.
- Produces a set of proposed child tasks (analysis, design spec, implementation spec, tests, docs) with acceptance criteria and suggested agent(s).
- Returns the top candidate and either recommends next steps or delegates the proposed tasks to named agents by creating wl child work-items and adding delegation comments.

Usage

Command-line
```
# Dry-run (default): discovery-only, returns recommendation and proposed tasks
python -m tools.skills.select_next_intake --dry-run

# Propose: create draft child work-items in wl (no stage changes)
python -m tools.skills.select_next_intake --propose --config config.yml

# Delegate: create child work-items and assign them to sub-agents (requires --approve or delegate policy)
python -m tools.skills.select_next_intake --delegate --assign-to analysis-agent,dev-agent --approve
```

API (Python)
```
from tools.skills.select_next_intake import select_next

result = select_next(mode='dry_run', filters={"min_priority":"medium"})
# result => {
#   "id": "WL-123",
#   "score": 87,
#   "rationale": "High priority, has acceptance criteria, no blockers",
#   "checks": [ {"name":"has_acceptance_criteria","ok":true}, ... ],
#   "proposed_tasks": [ {"title":"Analysis: scope & gaps", "assignee":"analysis-agent", ... } ],
#   "action": "recommend"
# }
```

Result schema
- id: string (work-item id)
- score: integer (0-100)
- rationale: short human-readable string
- checks: array of {name, ok, details}
- proposed_tasks: array of {title, description, acceptance_criteria, suggested_assignee_or_agent, priority}
- action: `recommend` | `propose` | `delegate`

Configuration
- Accepts JSON/YAML config to adjust scoring weights, filters, and delegation mapping (which tags map to which agent-groups).
- Default weights: weight(priority)=0.5, weight(acceptance)=0.2, weight(assignee)=0.2, weight(blockers)=0.1

Safety model
- Default mode is `dry_run` (read-only).
- `--propose` creates draft child work-items in `wl` but does not change the parent stage.
- `--delegate` assigns tasks to agents and may add delegation comments; it never performs repository pushes/merges. Any repository actions are left to delegated agents and require separate approval.
- All delegation actions are logged as comments on the parent work-item and child items, including timestamp, agent, mode, and rationale.

Testing
- Unit tests for scoring, checks, and proposed_tasks generation.
- Integration tests mocking `wl` outputs to verify that `propose` and `delegate` modes create the expected child items and comments without touching repositories.

Open questions / TODOs
- Finalize delegation mapping (tag -> agent-group) and default assignees.
- Define how to detect and represent "open blockers" in wl (relationships, tags, or explicit blocker fields).
- Define audit trail format for delegation actions and retention policy.

      "description": "Problem statement
AMPA Daemon: a small Python-based containerized daemon that monitors LLM agent activity and notifies a Discord channel via webhook. In v1 it will send periodic heartbeat notifications (configurable interval) indicating the agent is alive.

Users
- Operators running LLM agents on a single host who need lightweight visibility into agent liveness.
- Agent orchestrators and PM agents that expect simple alive/heartbeat signals for monitoring and basic automation.

Example user stories
- As an operator, I want a container I can run on the LLM server that regularly posts an "alive" message so I can see the agent is running.
- As an APMA integrator, I want the message to include the work-item id, hostname, and timestamp so I can correlate the signal with worklog items and hosts.

Success criteria
- Heartbeat messages are sent to the configured Discord webhook at the configured interval; default is 1 minute (env: AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES).
- Messages include work-item id (if available), host name, and ISO-8601 timestamp.
- The daemon reads webhook URL from env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` and fails clearly if not set.
- The service can be packaged in a container (Docker) and run with sensible defaults; logs are written to stdout/stderr for host/container logging.

Constraints
- V1 is read-only and only sends notifications; it does not modify repositories or create worklog items.
- Runtime: Python (3.12+ recommended) in a container image; minimal dependencies.
- Webhook URL must be supplied via env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` (security: do not commit secrets).
- Heartbeat interval must be configurable via env var `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES` (integer minutes), default 1.
- The container image and artifacts must be runnable with Podman (CLI-compatible with Docker); avoid Docker-only features that break Podman.

Existing state
- APMA PRD exists and describes an Automated PM Agent and related skills (see `docs/prd/PRD_Automated_PM_Agent_-_end-to-end_project_overseer_(SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR).md`).
- A related skill `select-next-intake-ready-item` exists as a design artifact and task (SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE) and shows how agents interact with wl.

Desired change
- Implement a minimal Python daemon that:
  - Reads `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` and `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES` from environment.
  - Posts a heartbeat message to the webhook at the configured interval.
  - Supports a configurable message template that includes work-item id, hostname, and timestamp.
  - Logs send attempts and failures to stdout with non-zero exit codes on fatal misconfiguration.
  - Is containerized with a small Dockerfile and a recommended command to run; ensure the image and Dockerfile work with Podman (no Docker-only features).

Related work
- docs/prd/PRD_Automated_PM_Agent_-_end-to-end_project_overseer_(SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR).md — PRD describing APMA responsibilities and constraints; high-level context for AMPA Daemon.
- skill/create-worktree-skill/SKILL.md — shows a pattern for agent worktrees and ephemeral agents.
- tools/skills/select_next_intake.py (design) / SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE — related skill design that will consume or correlate with daemon signals in future.
- .opencode/Workflow.md — repo workflow and safety model to follow.

Suggested next step
1) Build a minimal PoC container and run locally against a test Discord webhook. Steps:
   - Implement `ampa_daemon.py` (Python) that uses `requests` to POST to the webhook.
   - Add `Dockerfile` with `python:3.12-slim` base, expose no ports, run the daemon as the container CMD.
   - Test locally with `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` set to a test webhook and `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES=1`.

Notes / open questions (resolved)
- Deployment runtime: target is an OCI-compatible container runtime on the server (Docker/Podman); images and run instructions must be compatible with Podman.
- Completion notification: YES, include a completion notification capability in design, but mark it out-of-scope for MVP (implement in a later iteration).
- Message format: use Discord embed format for notifications (structured embed payload).
- Failure & retry policy: exponential backoff with up to 10 retry attempts on webhook failures; log each failed attempt and final failure.

- AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES (integer, default 1)
- AMPA_WORKITEM_ID (optional)

      "id": "SA-0ML7Q2XI11OO3S5I",
      "title": "Add command scheduling mechanism to APMA daemon",
      "description": "Summary:
Add a pluggable scheduling mechanism to the APMA daemon that defines which commands run, where they run (local host vs LLM server), and when they run. The scheduler must ensure only one command runs at a time, respect a global maximum run-frequency limit, and prefer commands that require an available LLM only when an LLM server is reachable.

User stories:
- As an operator, I can register commands with fields (id, command, requires_llm, frequency_minutes, priority, metadata) so the daemon knows what to run and how often.
- As the daemon, I will run at most one command at a time and will not start any command that requires an LLM unless an LLM server is available.
- As the scheduler, I will select the next command based on how overdue it is relative to its requested frequency, weighted by a priority, to keep actual run times close to requested frequencies.

Expected behaviour:
- New command entries can be added/removed at runtime (hot reload or via config API).
- Each command has: unique id, executable (shell string or defined action), requires_llm (bool), frequency_minutes (positive int), priority (integer or enum), last_run timestamp (nullable), and optional max_runtime_minutes.
- The daemon enforces a global minimum interval between any command starts ("max every x minutes") configurable.
- Only a single command can run concurrently.
- Commands that require LLM are only scheduled when an LLM server is known available. The scheduler should re-evaluate availability periodically.

Dependency:
- blocked-by:SA-0ML7OB15A0HU5NKZ

Suggested implementation approach:
- Add a persistent/serialisable schedule store (file or DB) that holds command definitions and last_run times.
- Add a scheduler component that:
  1) Polls every configurable short interval (eg. 30s) to decide if it should start a command.
  2) Observes the global rate limiter (do not start if last_start < now - global_min_interval).
  3) Computes a score for each eligible command and picks the command with the highest score.
  4) Starts the command, marks it running, updates last_run when it finishes (success or failure) and records runtime and exit code.
- Provide an LLM-availability probe used by the scheduler to mark LLM-required commands as temporarily ineligible.
- Expose a lightweight API or CLI to list, add, remove, and adjust scheduled commands.

Algorithm suggestions (goal: keep each command close to its requested frequency):
- Recommended algorithm: normalized-lateness weighted scheduler
  - For each command i, compute:
    - desired_interval = frequency_minutes_i * 60
    - time_since_last = now - last_run_i (if never run, treat last_run as epoch 0 or large value to prioritize initial run)
    - lateness = time_since_last - desired_interval
    - normalized_lateness = lateness / desired_interval  (commands with normalized_lateness>0 are overdue)
    - priority_factor = 1 + priority_weight * (priority_value)  (tuneable mapping, e.g. priority_value 0..10 => multiplier 1..2)
    - score = max(normalized_lateness, 0) * priority_factor
  - Pick the command with highest score among eligible commands. This balances proportional fairness (by frequency) and priority.
  - Add aging: if a lower-priority command never runs, its normalized_lateness grows unbounded and it eventually wins, preventing starvation.

- Alternative: proportional fair scheduling using ratio r = time_since_last / desired_interval, select highest r * priority_weight. Equivalent in practice to normalized-lateness for periodic scheduling.

- Notes on tuning: clamp negative lateness to 0 to avoid favouring early runs; add a small epsilon to denominators to avoid division by zero. Map priority to a multiplicative factor rather than additive to preserve relative frequency desires.

Acceptance criteria (measurable):
- A wl work item or config file schema is added describing command fields and persisted store location.
- Scheduler implemented with: store, eligibility checks (LLM availability & global rate limiter), selection algorithm, start/stop lifecycle, and metrics emitted for runs (start, finish, duration, exit code).
- Automated unit tests for scheduler scoring including edge cases: never-run commands, very-high-frequency commands, LLM-required when unavailable, global rate limiter.
- Integration test or simulation demonstrating that for a set of commands with varied frequencies and priorities, observed run times are within a reasonable bound (e.g. 10-20% average deviation) of requested frequencies over a simulated period.
- Documentation: README or code comments describing the algorithm, configuration knobs (global_min_interval, poll_interval, priority mapping), and how to add/modify commands.

What to deliver with this item:
- Implementation branch, tests, and documentation.
- Suggested tuning values and rationale for priority mapping.",

    {
      "id": "SA-0ML96LPVC19CD40C",
      "title": "Scheduler: issue triage (automatic wl in-progress audits)",
      "description": "Problem statement
-----------------
The scheduler must automatically triage in-progress Worklog items: every 2 minutes fetch `wl in-progress --json`, pick the item with the oldest `updatedAt` (least recently updated), run `opencode run audit <work-item-id>` against it, deliver a short summary to the configured Discord webhook, and post the full audit (truncated if necessary) as a comment on the work item.

Users
-----
- Operators and PMs who rely on timely visibility into stalled or neglected in-progress work items.
- The APMA / AMPA automation that needs regular audits surfaced to Slack/Discord and Worklog for human review.

Example user stories
- As an operator, I want the scheduler to alert the team when an in-progress item has not been updated for a long time, so I can reassign or unblock it.
- As an APMA integrator, I want automated audits posted to work items so humans have evidence of health checks and suggested next steps.

Success criteria
----------------
- Scheduler runs every 2 minutes and executes the triage flow end-to-end (fetch -> select -> audit -> deliver) with measurable logs.
- For each run: a short (1–3 line) summary is posted to Discord (via `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK`) and a concise summary comment is posted on the audited WL work item.
- Full audit output is attached to the work item as a comment (up to 64k chars); if longer, the comment references an attached artifact containing the full output.
- The system handles transient failures by relying on the global retry/backoff policy (no local retry logic implemented in this feature); any final failure is recorded as an error comment on the work item.

Constraints
-----------
- Use the global `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` environment variable for Discord delivery; do not embed webhook secrets in code or comments.
- Poll interval is configurable but defaults to every 2 minutes for this feature.
- No local retry logic will be implemented here; the feature defers to the global retry/backoff work (see SA-0ML7OB0NX0Z9T0YV). Implementation must be ready to integrate with a global retry later.
- Audit output may be large; comments must be truncated to 64k characters and include or link to an attached full-output artifact when necessary.
 - No single work item should be audited more frequently than once every 6 hours. Implementations must record a per-work-item `last_audit_at` timestamp and skip items audited within the cooldown window.

Existing state
--------------
- Scheduler and AMPA daemon exist and already support scheduled commands, Discord webhook posting, and `wl in-progress` as a scheduled command (see `ampa/scheduler.py` and `ampa/scheduler_store.json`).
- Related scheduler improvements and defaults have been implemented (moving heartbeat into scheduler config, switching to `wl in-progress`, plain-text webhook payloads).

Desired change / Implementation notes
-----------------------------------
- Add a new scheduler command spec (default in `ampa/scheduler_store.json`) named `wl-triage-audit` with frequency 2 minutes and metadata indicating it performs: `wl in-progress --json` -> select least-recently-updated -> `opencode run audit <id>`.
- Implement executor logic to:
  1) run `wl in-progress --json` and parse result;
  2) select the work item with the smallest `updatedAt` timestamp among those that have not been audited within the configured cooldown window (default 6 hours). If all in-progress items have been audited within the cooldown, the scheduler should skip the run.
  3) run `opencode run audit <work-item-id>` and capture stdout/stderr and exit status;
  4) post a short 1–3 line summary to the Discord webhook configured in `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` (include work-item id, title, and short status/exit code);
  5) post the full audit output as a comment on the work item, truncating the comment body at 64k characters and attaching the full output as an artifact if larger.
- Error handling: if an operation (wl in-progress, audit, discord post, wl comment) fails transiently, rely on global retry; on final failure post a WL comment with an error summary and log the failure.
- Config options to expose: `poll_interval_minutes` (default 2), `webhook_env_var` (default AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK), `workitem_comment_truncate_chars` (default 65536), and `verbosity` (summary vs verbose).
  - `audit_cooldown_hours` (default 6) — minimum time between audits of the same work item; implementers should persist `last_audit_at` on the item or in the scheduler store.

Related work
------------
- AMPA Daemon: Discord heartbeat & notifier — SA-0ML7NOSHP0MJC6HS (parent project; scheduler lives under this parent).
- Move heartbeat to scheduler config and add wl recent command — SA-0ML8QRQXC12R12DF (moved heartbeat into scheduler; related config work).
- Update scheduled commands to wl in-progress and wl stats — SA-0ML8VDYT303CDIWD (updated defaults to use `wl in-progress`).
- Scheduler daemon updates and docs — SA-0ML95LRFD08CS2CZ (scheduler cwd / docs changes already applied).
- Fix scheduler wl stats command — SA-0ML8XKRV80GORAL7 (related scheduler command fixes)
- Core Heartbeat Sender — SA-0ML7OB0H20XBQO6G (discord webhook formatting and retry policies; shared code paths).
- Implementation references: `ampa/scheduler.py`, `ampa/scheduler_schema.md`, `ampa/scheduler_store.json`, `AGENTS.md`, `skill/status/SKILL.md`.

Suggested next steps
--------------------
1) Proceed to implement a scheduler command and executor stub (create feature branch, add tests to cover happy path and error comment path). This step involves adding the scheduler store entry, implementing selection + audit invocation, and wiring Discord/comment posting. (Recommended next step)
2) Add integration tests that run the triage flow against a mocked `wl` and `opencode run` to verify idempotence, comment truncation and artifact attachment.
3) After implementation, update the Worklog work item description with this intake brief and mark stage `intake_complete`.

Notes / Open questions
----------------------
- We will use `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` as the webhook; if you want per-scheduler-entry webhooks, we can add `spec.metadata.webhook` as a fallback later.
- The feature defers to the global retry/backoff policy (SA-0ML7OB0NX0Z9T0YV). If you prefer local retries now, specify and we will add them.",

    "id": "SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR",
    "title": "Automated PM Agent — end-to-end project overseer",
    "description": "Summary:\nDesign, define, and build an Automated PM Agent (APMA) that acts as a discovery, definition, and delegation engine to coordinate delivery across human and automated sub-agents. The APMA's responsibility is to ensure clarity of plan, break down work into actionable tasks, assign or delegate those tasks, and monitor progress — it does not implement code changes or directly modify repositories.\n\nGoal / Scope:\nThe APMA intake flow accepts briefs and performs discovery to surface candidate work, creates clear work definitions (analysis, design, implementation spec, test plan, docs), and delegates those tasks to appropriate agents or teams. It sequences and coordinates work, triggers or requests non-destructive checks (builds/tests in read-only mode), and reports status, risks, and blockers. All code or repository modifications are executed by delegated agents (people or automation) under explicit approval policies.\n\nUser stories:\n- As a product lead, I want the APMA to turn a high-level brief into a clear plan with defined tasks and assignees so work can start without ambiguous follow-ups.\n- As an engineer or sub-agent, I want the APMA to produce unambiguous child work-items (analysis, design spec, implementation spec, tests, docs) with acceptance criteria so I can execute my assigned work with minimal additional discovery.\n- As a stakeholder, I want the APMA to delegate work to named agents, maintain an audit trail of delegation actions, and produce regular progress reports so I can monitor delivery.\n- As a safety officer, I want the APMA to default to read-only discovery and never perform destructive repo operations without explicit separate approval.\n\nExpected behaviour / outcomes:\n- The APMA discovers and ranks candidate items from `idea` stage, runs readiness checks, and returns a clear recommended plan with proposed child tasks and suggested assignees/agent-groups.\n- The APMA can create draft child work-items or add delegation comments in `wl` to record what should be done and who should do it; it may assign tasks to agent identities but will not perform repository pushes, merges, or direct code edits.\n- The APMA coordinates non-destructive operations (CI runs in dry-run mode, linting, static analysis) and attaches results to work-items; any mutating repository actions are delegated and require separate approvals.\n- The APMA generates progress summaries (open/blocked items, percent complete, top risks) and maintains an auditable comment trail for decisions and delegations.\n- The APMA can also generate new ideas for exploration (research spikes, prototypes, alternative approaches) and surface them as candidate `idea`-stage work-items for further discovery.\n- The APMA can respond clearly about the status of any particular work-item or group of work-items, providing current stage, recent activity, assigned agents, blockers, and next recommended actions.\n\nAcceptance criteria:\n1) Given a project brief, the APMA creates an epic with child work-items that define discovery tasks, analysis, design, implementation spec, testing, and documentation steps with measurable acceptance criteria in `wl`.\n2) The APMA can produce a delegation plan for a selected work-item: a list of proposed child tasks, suggested assignee agent-groups, and the rationale for each delegation (verify: `wl show` and comments reflect proposed tasks and rationale).\n3) The APMA provides read-only discovery by default; `propose` or `delegate` actions create draft child work-items or comments but do not modify code repositories. Any `apply` mode that triggers repository changes must be explicitly approved and executed by delegated agents.\n4) The APMA produces human-readable progress reports and an audit trail of delegation actions attached to the relevant work-items.\n\nSuggested implementation approach:\n- Phase 1 (define): Create PRD, agent responsibilities, safety/permission model, and minimal architecture (core controller + plug-in subagents for wl, delegation, reporting).\n- Phase 2 (MVP): Implement intake parser, discovery scorer, task composer, delegation planner (creates draft child work-items and comments), and reporting module. Keep all repo-affecting steps as outputs for delegated agents.\n- Phase 3 (operate): Integrate with sub-agents (analysis-agent, design-agent, dev-agent, test-agent), refine delegation mappings, and add audit and reporting enhancements.\n\nDeliverables:\n- PRD and design doc stored in the repo describing discovery/definition/delegation model and safety policy.\n- APMA components (service/CLI) that implement the MVP acceptance criteria above, but do not perform direct repository mutations.\n- Tests validating `wl` creations, proposed delegations, and reporting behavior.\n\nNotes / constraints:\n- APMA is non-destructive by default: repository changes are outside its remit and must be performed by delegates under separate approvals.\n- Follow repo conventions for task naming, branch suggestions, and commit message drafts; these should be provided as outputs for delegates, not applied by APMA.\n- Maintain clear audit logs in work-items when delegations or proposals are created.\n\nAcceptance test steps:\n- Run APMA with a sample brief and verify an epic is created with well-defined child tasks: `wl show <epic-id>`.\n- Verify the APMA produced a delegation plan and comments suggesting assignees/agent-groups for child tasks.\n- Confirm APMA's operations did not perform any repository pushes or merges; repository-affecting steps are present as delegated outputs only.\n- Generate the APMA progress report and confirm it lists open/blocked items, percent complete, and top risks.\n\nRelated: SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE (select-next-intake-ready-item) and other skills that focus on discovery and delegation.",

      "id": "SA-0ML7NOSHP0MJC6HS",
      "title": "AMPA Daemon: Discord heartbeat & notifier",
      "description": "Problem statement
AMPA Daemon: a small Python-based containerized daemon that monitors LLM agent activity and notifies a Discord channel via webhook. In v1 it will send periodic heartbeat notifications (configurable interval) indicating the agent is alive.

Users
- Operators running LLM agents on a single host who need lightweight visibility into agent liveness.
- Agent orchestrators and PM agents that expect simple alive/heartbeat signals for monitoring and basic automation.

Example user stories
- As an operator, I want a container I can run on the LLM server that regularly posts an "alive" message so I can see the agent is running.
- As an APMA integrator, I want the message to include the work-item id, hostname, and timestamp so I can correlate the signal with worklog items and hosts.

Success criteria
- Heartbeat messages are sent to the configured Discord webhook at the configured interval; default is 1 minute (env: AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES).
- Messages include work-item id (if available), host name, and ISO-8601 timestamp.
- The daemon reads webhook URL from env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` and fails clearly if not set.
- The service can be packaged in a container (Docker) and run with sensible defaults; logs are written to stdout/stderr for host/container logging.

Constraints
- V1 is read-only and only sends notifications; it does not modify repositories or create worklog items.
- Runtime: Python (3.12+ recommended) in a container image; minimal dependencies.
- Webhook URL must be supplied via env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` (security: do not commit secrets).
- Heartbeat interval must be configurable via env var `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES` (integer minutes), default 1.
- The container image and artifacts must be runnable with Podman (CLI-compatible with Docker); avoid Docker-only features that break Podman.

Existing state
- APMA PRD exists and describes an Automated PM Agent and related skills (see `docs/prd/PRD_Automated_PM_Agent_-_end-to-end_project_overseer_(SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR).md`).
- A related skill `select-next-intake-ready-item` exists as a design artifact and task (SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE) and shows how agents interact with wl.

Desired change
- Implement a minimal Python daemon that:
  - Reads `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` and `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES` from environment.
  - Posts a heartbeat message to the webhook at the configured interval.
  - Supports a configurable message template that includes work-item id, hostname, and timestamp.
  - Logs send attempts and failures to stdout with non-zero exit codes on fatal misconfiguration.
  - Is containerized with a small Dockerfile and a recommended command to run; ensure the image and Dockerfile work with Podman (no Docker-only features).

      "id": "SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR",
      "title": "Automated PM Agent — end-to-end project overseer",
      "description": "Summary:
Design, define, and build an Automated PM Agent (APMA) that acts as a discovery, definition, and delegation engine to coordinate delivery across human and automated sub-agents. The APMA's responsibility is to ensure clarity of plan, break down work into actionable tasks, assign or delegate those tasks, and monitor progress — it does not implement code changes or directly modify repositories.

Goal / Scope:
The APMA intake flow accepts briefs and performs discovery to surface candidate work, creates clear work definitions (analysis, design, implementation spec, test plan, docs), and delegates those tasks to appropriate agents or teams. It sequences and coordinates work, triggers or requests non-destructive checks (builds/tests in read-only mode), and reports status, risks, and blockers. All code or repository modifications are executed by delegated agents (people or automation) under explicit approval policies.

User stories:
- As a product lead, I want the APMA to turn a high-level brief into a clear plan with defined tasks and assignees so work can start without ambiguous follow-ups.
- As an engineer or sub-agent, I want the APMA to produce unambiguous child work-items (analysis, design spec, implementation spec, tests, docs) with acceptance criteria so I can execute my assigned work with minimal additional discovery.
- As a stakeholder, I want the APMA to delegate work to named agents, maintain an audit trail of delegation actions, and produce regular progress reports so I can monitor delivery.
- As a safety officer, I want the APMA to default to read-only discovery and never perform destructive repo operations without explicit separate approval.

Expected behaviour / outcomes:
- The APMA discovers and ranks candidate items from `idea` stage, runs readiness checks, and returns a clear recommended plan with proposed child tasks and suggested assignees/agent-groups.
- The APMA can create draft child work-items or add delegation comments in `wl` to record what should be done and who should do it; it may assign tasks to agent identities but will not perform repository pushes, merges, or direct code edits.
- The APMA coordinates non-destructive operations (CI runs in dry-run mode, linting, static analysis) and attaches results to work-items; any mutating repository actions are delegated and require separate approvals.
- The APMA generates progress summaries (open/blocked items, percent complete, top risks) and maintains an auditable comment trail for decisions and delegations.
- The APMA can also generate new ideas for exploration (research spikes, prototypes, alternative approaches) and surface them as candidate `idea`-stage work-items for further discovery.
- The APMA can respond clearly about the status of any particular work-item or group of work-items, providing current stage, recent activity, assigned agents, blockers, and next recommended actions.

Acceptance criteria:
1) Given a project brief, the APMA creates an epic with child work-items that define discovery tasks, analysis, design, implementation spec, testing, and documentation steps with measurable acceptance criteria in `wl`.
2) The APMA can produce a delegation plan for a selected work-item: a list of proposed child tasks, suggested assignee agent-groups, and the rationale for each delegation (verify: `wl show` and comments reflect proposed tasks and rationale).
3) The APMA provides read-only discovery by default; `propose` or `delegate` actions create draft child work-items or comments but do not modify code repositories. Any `apply` mode that triggers repository changes must be explicitly approved and executed by delegated agents.
4) The APMA produces human-readable progress reports and an audit trail of delegation actions attached to the relevant work-items.

Suggested implementation approach:
- Phase 1 (define): Create PRD, agent responsibilities, safety/permission model, and minimal architecture (core controller + plug-in subagents for wl, delegation, reporting).
- Phase 2 (MVP): Implement intake parser, discovery scorer, task composer, delegation planner (creates draft child work-items and comments), and reporting module. Keep all repo-affecting steps as outputs for delegated agents.
- Phase 3 (operate): Integrate with sub-agents (analysis-agent, design-agent, dev-agent, test-agent), refine delegation mappings, and add audit and reporting enhancements.

Deliverables:
- PRD and design doc stored in the repo describing discovery/definition/delegation model and safety policy.
- APMA components (service/CLI) that implement the MVP acceptance criteria above, but do not perform direct repository mutations.
- Tests validating `wl` creations, proposed delegations, and reporting behavior.

Notes / constraints:
- APMA is non-destructive by default: repository changes are outside its remit and must be performed by delegates under separate approvals.
- Follow repo conventions for task naming, branch suggestions, and commit message drafts; these should be provided as outputs for delegates, not applied by APMA.
- Maintain clear audit logs in work-items when delegations or proposals are created.

Acceptance test steps:
- Run APMA with a sample brief and verify an epic is created with well-defined child tasks: `wl show <epic-id>`.
- Verify the APMA produced a delegation plan and comments suggesting assignees/agent-groups for child tasks.
- Confirm APMA's operations did not perform any repository pushes or merges; repository-affecting steps are present as delegated outputs only.
- Generate the APMA progress report and confirm it lists open/blocked items, percent complete, and top risks.

Related: SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE (select-next-intake-ready-item) and other skills that focus on discovery and delegation.",

      "id": "SA-0ML7NOSHP0MJC6HS",
      "title": "AMPA Daemon: Discord heartbeat & notifier",
      "description": "Problem statement
AMPA Daemon: a small Python-based containerized daemon that monitors LLM agent activity and notifies a Discord channel via webhook. In v1 it will send periodic heartbeat notifications (configurable interval) indicating the agent is alive.

Users
- Operators running LLM agents on a single host who need lightweight visibility into agent liveness.
- Agent orchestrators and PM agents that expect simple alive/heartbeat signals for monitoring and basic automation.

Example user stories
- As an operator, I want a container I can run on the LLM server that regularly posts an "alive" message so I can see the agent is running.
- As an APMA integrator, I want the message to include the work-item id, hostname, and timestamp so I can correlate the signal with worklog items and hosts.

Success criteria
- Heartbeat messages are sent to the configured Discord webhook at the configured interval; default is 1 minute (env: AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES).
- Messages include work-item id (if available), host name, and ISO-8601 timestamp.
- The daemon reads webhook URL from env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` and fails clearly if not set.
- The service can be packaged in a container (Docker) and run with sensible defaults; logs are written to stdout/stderr for host/container logging.

Constraints
- V1 is read-only and only sends notifications; it does not modify repositories or create worklog items.
- Runtime: Python (3.12+ recommended) in a container image; minimal dependencies.
- Webhook URL must be supplied via env var `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` (security: do not commit secrets).
- Heartbeat interval must be configurable via env var `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES` (integer minutes), default 1.
- The container image and artifacts must be runnable with Podman (CLI-compatible with Docker); avoid Docker-only features that break Podman.

Existing state
- APMA PRD exists and describes an Automated PM Agent and related skills (see `docs/prd/PRD_Automated_PM_Agent_-_end-to-end_project_overseer_(SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR).md`).
- A related skill `select-next-intake-ready-item` exists as a design artifact and task (SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE) and shows how agents interact with wl.

Desired change
- Implement a minimal Python daemon that:
  - Reads `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` and `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES` from environment.
  - Posts a heartbeat message to the webhook at the configured interval.
  - Supports a configurable message template that includes work-item id, hostname, and timestamp.
  - Logs send attempts and failures to stdout with non-zero exit codes on fatal misconfiguration.
  - Is containerized with a small Dockerfile and a recommended command to run; ensure the image and Dockerfile work with Podman (no Docker-only features).

Related work
- docs/prd/PRD_Automated_PM_Agent_-_end-to-end_project_overseer_(SA-0ML5E2A2V1YILTVR).md — PRD describing APMA responsibilities and constraints; high-level context for AMPA Daemon.
- skill/create-worktree-skill/SKILL.md — shows a pattern for agent worktrees and ephemeral agents.
- tools/skills/select_next_intake.py (design) / SA-0ML5E7ZHH0Y5VJQE — related skill design that will consume or correlate with daemon signals in future.
- .opencode/Workflow.md — repo workflow and safety model to follow.

Suggested next step
1) Build a minimal PoC container and run locally against a test Discord webhook. Steps:
   - Implement `ampa_daemon.py` (Python) that uses `requests` to POST to the webhook.
   - Add `Dockerfile` with `python:3.12-slim` base, expose no ports, run the daemon as the container CMD.
   - Test locally with `AMPA_DISCORD_WEBHOOK` set to a test webhook and `AMPA_HEARTBEAT_MINUTES=1`.

Notes / open questions (resolved)
- Deployment runtime: target is an OCI-compatible container runtime on the server (Docker/Podman); images and run instructions must be compatible with Podman.
- Completion notification: YES, include a completion notification capability in design, but mark it out-of-scope for MVP (implement in a later iteration).
- Message format: use Discord embed format for notifications (structured embed payload).
- Failure & retry policy: exponential backoff with up to 10 retry attempts on webhook failures; log each failed attempt and final failure.

Work item id
